Description: Pendant or bead of irregular shape, on roughly triangular base; rosette to the front, loop behind.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to the EEF distribution list annotated in Boston, P.5243 is supposed to be a head of Bes, pale green glaze with brown eyes. Perhaps it was mixed up with the rosette pendant now featuring under P.5245.

A bead of related type was found in a domestic context dated c. 450-350BC within the Persian Period forteress at Migdol/Tell el-Herr in the Sinai peninsula on the fringes of the Eastern Nile Delta: Marchi 2014, 91 fig. 126h. However, unlike the bead from Tell el-Herr, which has white petals with a dark centre, the bead here is uniformly coloured, and the findspot seems to suggest an earlier date. Marchi, S. , L'habitat dans les forteresses de Migdol (Tell el-Herr) durant les Ve et IVe siècles avant. J.-C. Étude archéologique, Paris.
Xia type PD93. Xia, N. 2014, Ancient Egyptian Beads, Heidelberg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (QG.07)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5243 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
